International A2-10 Chernobyl still has problems two years after an explosion and fire. The nuclear power station is riddled with negligence, and managers have ignored safety regulations, the Soviet newspaper Pravda charged. Page A1 Soviet economic change has failed so far to produce much growth or raise living standards, despite the ambitious programs of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to a U.S. intelligence analysis. D1 A careful call for religious freedom in the Soviet Union was delivered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who attended a Mass at the Georgian Orthodox Cathedral in Tbilisi before leaving for Brussels. A7 Anti-missile systems using rockets instead of lasers are vulnerable to equipment and computer software failures that would make them unworkable, according to a Congressional research agency. A8 President Mitterrand took the lead over Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in the elimination round of France's presidential elections and appeared to be the front-runner in a run-off vote against Mr. Chirac on May 8. A1 Yasir Arafat arrived in Damascus in an a effort to achieve a reconcilliation with Syria after a five-year rift. The P.L.O. chairman is expected to meet President Hafez al-Assad for talks on the Middle East. A1 Israel reopened the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the first time in a week and ended the 24-hour curfews. Army officials said the steps were rewards for ''relative calm'' in the occupied territories. A3 A gold rush in Brazil's jungles has drawn at least 500,000 people into the country's wild interior, where, with primitive tools, they have made Brazil the world's fifth-largest gold producer. A10 South Vietnam's middle class all but disappeared after the war ended in 1975. While many Southeast Asians have risen to higher income levels in the last decade, many in Vietnam have sunk to the peasantry. A4 Prime Minister Brian Mulroney will push Washington for more cooperation on the problem of acid rain when the Canadian leader meets President Reagan and addresses a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday. A10 Toll in Lebanese explosion is 66; Moslems blame Christians A2 Consultation is pledged on gulf role A3 A restive island tribe adds to Noriega's woes A6 National A14-19, B6-7 An explosion and fire aboard the sub-marine U.S.S. Bonefish yesterday left 18 sailors injured, three in serious condition, and 3 of the 92-member crew missing, according to the Navy. A1 Acid rain's effects on the Atlantic coastal waters is greater than previously recognized, according to a report, and contributed to large, temporary die-offs of marine life along the northeastern coast. A1 Overcrowding in the nation's prisons is forcing officials to reassess sentencing practices. But despite the costs of building new prisons, a widespread fear of crime makes a dramatic shift in policies unlikely. A1 Academic performance remains low in American primary and secondary schools, according to Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, despite movements over the last five years to raise standards. A1 Resignations of top Justice officials have left no one at the Department to push several important legal initiatives sought by the Reagan Administration but have not affected day-to-day operations, officials say. A16 A $1.2 billion takeover offer for J. P. Stevens & Company, among the biggest textile producers in the country, has been accepted from West Point-Pepperell Inc., a major competitor. But Republicans have done better in statewide races. B1 Problems in the prosecution's case will prevent the conviction of two men accused of murdering a New York City police detective, predicted a Queens minister who served on the jury that deadlocked in the case. B2 Public services in New York City are not equal to what the public pays, according to a report by a citizens group. It rated refuse collection excellent, street cleaning poor and other services passable. B3 Legislation to help single mothers move off welfare and find jobs, now in Congress, will provide some new funds but is unlikely to produce dramatic changes in New York City's welfare programs, officials say.
